About Me

"Don't let the world change your smile, but let your smile change the world"

Hello there! I'm Michael Ah and I'd like to thank you for browsing my website. If you don't know me, I am a passionate 21 year old engineering student studying at the University of Calgary. I come from Mauritius, a small tropical island by the coast of south Africa. I speak fluent French, Creole and English. I am a practicising Christian, and a strong believer that we make this world a better place by showing kindness regardless of our internal and external struggles. My hobbies consist of coding, hiking and watching/playing soccer. If I'm not at my desk answering your emails, you'll have to come find me in the mountains!

I am currently employed at Hexagon Autonomy & positioning as an R&D Engineering Intern. I have industry experience in software development, research and working on agile teams. On the side, I am an investor with experience day trading. My main portfolio consists of 40% tech, 20% energy, 20% financials, 15% reit and 5% airlines.

Academic Aspiration

"If you always worry about today, you'll never enjoy tomorrow"

I am in my final year of Geomatics Engineering with a long list of success and awards under my name. From 2016 to 2018 I was in a biomedical specializaton before getting into a computer science minor in 2019. I registered in the department of Geomatics Engineering because of my interest in lidar data, GNSS (Global Navigation Satelite Systems) positioning and autonomous driving. In the future I would like to get involved in autonomy and deep learning.

I plan on going into further education with a master of engineering in software development at the University of Calgary. I hope to learn new modern technoogy such as Machine Learning, Artificial Intelligence and Deep learning and how they can contribute to autonomy. Afterwards I hope to enter a graduate program in applied computer science at Dalhousie University. They have a strong program in mobile computing, data management and machine learning.

Volunteerism

"If not me, who? If not now, when?

In recent years, I’ve been an active leader in my community while excelling in my academics. I volunteer at my local church on weekends and help organize events at school with the Geomatics Engineering Student Society as their vice president. I occasionally volunteer at the drop-in center, the mustard seed and at “feed the hungry” events!

In the past, I have been involved with Fuse Collective in helping design a shelter for twin view community garden. Fuse collective is an engineering and design club that creates, designs and participates in real initiatives with real-world impact. Right now, I am mentoring two engineering students through the Seymour Schulich Scholars program.

I am also a frequent contributor to various charities such as the Tom Baker Center, Children Believe, the World Food Programme and the Plan International Canada. I have a strong predisposition and inclination to the crisis in the middle east (especially Syria and Yemen) and I'd like to take this opportunity to invite to help dying and starving children. There are plenty of ways to help including monetary donations, spreading the word or even mentioning it to your friend at wings night!

National Geomatics Engineering Competition

"The mortality rate for people who play it safe and for people who live bodly is the same, 100%"

"The National Geomatics Competition (NGC) is a student-led consulting engineering competition based in the field of Geomatics. Our focus is to bring together students and industry representatives from across the country. From the east to the west, NGC is now moving into Central Canada as the University of Waterloo hosts NGC 2020." - National Geomatics Committee

In 2020, I had the privilege of representing the University of Calgary at the National Geomatics Engineering Competition hosted in Waterloo. The 2020 iteration was about combinining new positioning systems with modern technology to design an LRT station in the City of Guelp. My team and I strove hard making it to the final rounds before eventually losing to the University of New Brunswick and Universite Laval. It was my utmost honor to represent Calgary and bring home the bronze medal.
